EGX Rezzed Birmingham: Summary

31/03/2014

EGX Rezzed, one of the biggest game conventions in Britain came to the NEC on March 28th-30th. Alex Killeen went along and here he gives us the rundown

Image by

By undefined undefined

As I walked into the huge conference hall in the NEC, Birmingham, the place was sprawling with the biggest variety of game stands I could have expected - indie games, AAA titles, and even an alpha version of Alien: Isolation. Not being in possession of a coveted next-gen console, the game stands showcasing Titanfall, Infamous: Second Son and Murdered: Soul Suspect instantly drew my attention. With two of these three already released, my attention for the first two was merely an inquisitive one whilst my interest in Murdered: Soul Suspect was one that was spurned by the thought of a future release. Imagine L.A. Noire mixed with The Sixth Sense with a sprinkling of demons. This interesting approach to police investigating a murder (namely his own) made for an enthralling experience with some intriguing and expansive gameplay. After approaching these, I made my way to the Alien: Isolation stand, that had a good hour-long queue. But after the disappointment of Aliens: Colonial Marines, I had to see what the next title set in this universe had to offer. And it did not disappoint. As an alpha it had obvious problems: a bit of lack-lustre polishing and some minor performance issues, but these problems are to be expected from such an early version. Otherwise the experience was enthralling. Terrifying and atmospheric, that recalled the first experience I had with games like Slender and Amnesia: The Dark Descent. The fact that they made you play in a darkened environment did not help one bit. But I should move on to the crux of EGX Rezzed and that was the presence of the various smaller developers and games that will make their appearances mainly on the PSN store, the Xbox Marketplace and Steam. A few titles spring to mind that did not impress as much as others: Olli Olli (a skating game for the PlayStation Vita), Final Horizon (a tower defence game for the PlayStation 4 and PS Vita), and Not a Hero (a 2D cover-shooter for PC and next-gen consoles) all caught my attention. However, upon getting into the demos, I found them to have weird difficulty curves and mechanics that didn't necessarily work. At one point with all of them, I began to question whether I was just plain bad at the games, whether they had the weird aforementioned difficulty curves, or if they all still had bugs to be worked out. I mention the latter because before I sat down to play these titles, I watched those before me have the same infuriating experiences that made them drop the controllers and leave. But it wasn't all bad, titles from a UK indie publishing company, Mastertronic Games, amazed me. Overruled is a pleasant brawler-like title that has several modes of play that alternate every 30 seconds or so to keep the feeling fresh. 10 Second Ninja is a wonderful concept that mixes the frustration of Super Meat Boy with evil Nazi robots that challenge you to keep improving and improving. Tango Fiesta, a particular highlight of the entire day, is a witty and simple 2D topdown cooperative shooter. What makes it so different and witty, however, is its wonderful homages to the classic '80s action movies and the cheesiness that goes hand in hand with them. Speaking of 1980s-themed top-down shooters, Hotline Miami is back with Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number. And if memory serves it's just as good as ever. Mixing that colourful 1980s aesthetic and music with even more frustrating and hyper-violent action. The fun experience made me put my head down in shame, especially when you have spectators behind you criticising your each and every move. They did soon realise, however, that the game was much harder than they thought. There were many other titles worth mentioning such as Worms: Battlegrounds, Broforce and One Spear Arena. But the previous titles mentioned deserve slightly more emphasis. One more game did particularly stand out to me though. This was Luftrausers. Already released, but this deceptively simple 2D plane-game has you fly round a 2D environment trying to destroy as many enemies as possible. With plane types, weapons and manoeuvrability options, the game becomes the epitome of addictive, replayable gaming, constantly calling you back for more. Games were not the only things available during this conference. Taking the chance, I also dropped in on a couple of the developer sessions. One for a funny and interactive presentation from the developers of Tango Fiesta revealed that their game stemmed from the previous year's Creative Assembly game jam. After losing the jam, the team decided to go forward and make the game. It turned from inane and silly action directed towards foliage, influenced by the scene from Predator, and developed into a fully functional shooter incorporating as many '80s action tropes they could fit in. It was a humble affair, and the developers showed they slight zany natures and their genuine dedication to producing a fun, cooperative title. The next conference was much more profoundly scientific and, to an extent, philosophical. Mike Cook, of Goldsmiths' Computational, Creativity Group, has designed an AI called Angelina and her function is to create video games. A computer scientist, with a love of gaming, wanted to see if a computer could make computer games. Obviously the designs he showed us were simple and a bit weird, but the technology was astounding. The AI could make games about anything and actually began to invent its own game mechanics. While astounding and interesting from a technological standpoint, he emphasized the importance of this work in the future and the place of AI in game design, pointing to potential of such AIs to displace humans in the realms of game development - an eerie and thankfully, long-sighted prediction. All in all, EGX Rezzed this year was a stimulating, intriguing, and genuinely fun experience. It pointed out the strong stance that indie developers now have in the gaming community and that it isn't all just about those AAA titles anymore. After visiting, my faith has been renewed in the creativity and individuality of the gaming industry, especially that which is made in Britain.
